bibl.title: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, June 20, 1921

div1.p: Fisher reports on the malaria situation in South Carolina. He discusses his malaria control work funded by the Rockefeller Foundation.

div1.head: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, June 20, 1921
div1.opener:

DIRECTOR

DIVISION OF MALARIA CONTROL

ROBERT WILSON, JR., M. D., CHM., CHARLESTON
R. A. MARSH, M. D. " " " EDGEFIELD
C. C. CAMPBELL, M. D. " " ASHEVILLE
E. A. HINES, M. D. " " " " SENECA
W. J. SURDELL, M. D. " " " LUGOFF
WM. EGLESTON, M. D. " " HARTSVILLE
W. W. DODSON, PH. D. " " GREENVILLE
W. M. LESTER, M. D. " " " COLUMBIA
S. M. WOLFE, ATTY GEN. " " COLUMBIA
W. V. SUTHERLAND, COMP. GEN. " COLUMBIA
---------
JAMES A. HAYNE, M. D.
SECRETARY AND STATE HEALTH OFFICER
COLUMBIA June 20, 1921.
Dr. H. R. Carter, Asst. Surgeon General
U. S. Public Health Service
2121 California Avenue, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Complying with your letter of a few days
ago, I am sending you a copy of my letter of June 2nd
which contains figures with reference to malaria pre-
valence along Wateree river, in Fairfield County.
Since writing you, we took a census of some fifty houses
further away from the river toward Ridgeway, and find
the following results:

We took this second census in a section
of the country where we believe the river could not have
effected the malaria rate. This gives us a control, and
when the two groups are compared it leads one to infer
that the pond may have effected the occurence of malaria
to a greater distance than has been considered likely
heretofore. Both censuses were taken by the same person
in the same way.

At the request of the Power Company, I
recently made a trip to the pond and found practically
no breeding at the present time. The pond is about
seven feet below the crest of the dam. The water is all
drawn out of the shallows and the edges are clean. I
could see very few top minnows. I imagine that many of them
have been eaten by game fish, since there does not appear to
be much protection for them. The timber has been cut out
of the pond, with the exception a small strip in
Dutchman creek, up to the high water mark. The pond no
doubt looks entirely different when it is full, and the
-2-
gage readings at the Power houses show that from about
July 20th on, the pond was full until about the twelth of
October. At times, from two to four feet of water passed
over the crest of the dam for days at a time.

I have not made any recommendations to the
Company as to what should be done. This Power project is
a particular favorite with Mr. Duke who owns the Southern
Power Company. Men from all over the world come to visit
the plant. The Company is proud of it and the way it is
operated, and wants to feel just as proud of the way they
handle the malaria problem as they are of the other
features. They want to employ a man to do this work. I
had in mind suggesting to them that a number of fish
hatcheries be established just a little below high water
mark; so that when the pond rises, these little hatcheries
will be flooded out and the top minnows can scatter all
through the shallow portion of the pond. When the pond
goes down, the hatcheries should be cleaned of game
fish and restocked with minnows. Possibly by employing a
small force of men the fish could be given enough assist-
ance to effect a pretty high degree of control. Mr. Duke
has built a fine road from Great Falls to Wateree, thirty
six miles along the pond. The Great Falls Farm Company
a subsidiary of the Southern Power Company, is planning to
build about fifty houses for a Farming colony this year,
the contract already having been left. The plan is to
develope the agricultural possibilities along the pond.
The land is owned by the Company for a distance of approxi-
mately one mile from the high water mark.

With reference to the situation at Chester,
the pond Griffith referred to is a swimming pond about six
miles from the town. The owner permits no fishing at all.
He lives at the pond which is only about one-half mile
in diameter and is well stocked with fish. We examined
it on several occasions during the summer, and found very
few larvae, and I think there was very little if any pro-
duction. He also operates a small grist mill which gives
a beneficial fluctuation in the water level. We carefully
went over our records and eliminated all the cases which
might have been typhoid.

Replying to your inquiry as to what I am doing
in this state, I am directing the cooperative malaria
control demonstration work, and am trying to build up a
division of malaria control in the State Board of Health,
for which purposes the Rockefeller people gave us $5,000
in addition to the money appropriated for demonstration
work. It was in connection with the latter feature of
-3-
the work, that I became involved in the Wateree pond
project, since a large number of complaints were received
by the State Board of Health with reference to the amount
of malaria prevailing along the river.

I am training two young men who graduated last
year, and expect to add another one to our force before
long. We are looking after the maintenance work at Bam-
berg, Chester and Hartsville, and are working at the
towns of Fairfax and Beaufort. I think we will be able
to induce one or two other towns to take up the work
sometime during the summer.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours L.M. Fisher
Associate Sanitary Engineer.
